{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3252120,"name":"Jaci","username":"Jaci","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/jaci/{size}/8002_2.png","created_at":"2023-11-11T13:12:27.608Z","cooked":"

If you’ve seen the “Who’s on the CAN Bus” thread, you may have noticed vendor 6 – Grapple Robotics †. Who are they, and what do they do?

Well, Grapple Robotics is my company, or perhaps more accurately, me – a one-woman band, and basically – we’re gearing up to be a vendor for electronic and software products in FRC. In the early days, this was starting work on Pathfinder v2. After a bit of a hiatus, we’re back – as a registered business and all.

Today I’d like to take you on the development journey of a product I’ve been working on for the last ~6 months, but unfortunately won’t be releasing (at least not yet) due to reasons I’ll talk about later. That product is the SpiderLAN.

image940×448 67.9 KB

The evolution of the SpiderLAN.

What’s a SpiderLAN?

To put it simply, the SpiderLAN is an Ethernet switch built for FRC. In its most recent revision, it features six ethernet ports, two of which provide 18V regulated passive PoE. The board features a wide input voltage range of 4.75V – 16V, with PoE blackout at 3.5V. The power supply is double-redundant (pluggable terminal block + barrel jack), with non-PoE features also being powered over USB and through the RoboRIO MXP port. It features a USB Type-C interface which manages the switch, but also acts as a USB-to-Ethernet bridge. It has four digital I/O channels, and CAN bus connectivity. The SpiderLAN can either be mounted to the RoboRIO via the MXP interface or operate completely independently.

image914×725 112 KB

The SpiderLAN Rev 5 up close.

The board also features expansion headers, allowing for “shields” to be developed to further enhance its capability. The SpiderLAN also supports VLAN tagging, as well as a pretty cool thing I call “uplink-failover”.

Why aren’t you releasing this?

There’re a few reasons, but primarily it’s due to the release of the new radio in 2025 – featuring multiple ethernet ports. We were initially targeting a release timeline of November 2023, however, not only is this timeline ambitious, we were also a bit late to the table and unable to get this device approved as a PoE provider by FIRST for the 2024 game, pushing release out to 2025 at the earliest if teams want to make full use of the board. With a new radio on the horizon, I don’t expect there to be much of a market for this device now – but I’m happy to be proven wrong. If this sounds like something you want, make your voice heard and maybe you’ll see it in 2025.

The Development Journey

The SpiderLAN didn’t actually start out with the intention to be used onboard FRC robots! In fact, it was designed to be part of the JMS electrical subsystem – providing a combined network switch and digital I/O interface for each driver station using the JMS custom field management system, with the I/O being used for the team Emergency Stop buttons. And we used it exactly for that purpose in WARP 2023. With zero downtime (except for one match that we had to replay because someone tripped over the power cable), the board proved it’s ability. Don’t worry, I’ll be doing another post on JMS at some point, since that’s a whole different system worth exploring.

Revision 1 was very simplistic, it was barely more than the Ethernet switch IC and the microcontroller, with most pins broken out for debugging purposes. In fact, the MCU and the Ethernet Switch were not connected internally, requiring an external cable to enable the “smarts” of the device. The biggest mistake in this revision, though, was the use of a linear regulator, which got to a toasty 100 degrees Celsius when provided with 12V input power.

image811×739 82.8 KB

SpiderLAN Revision 1

Revision 2 and 3 followed on lessons learnt from Revision 1. With connection between the MCU and Ethernet Switch IC verified in Revision 1, we connected them internally. We also introduced switch-mode power regulation, and pluggable terminal blocks to allow the device to be quickly disconnected and replaced without screwing around with a ton of WAGO connectors. In Revision 2, we found that the voltage swing on the switch mode power supply was too noisy, causing the MCU’s Ethernet transceiver to be operating out-of-spec and eventually burn out on all five out of five boards, so you’ll notice the power regulation gaining a beefy LC filter on both the 18V and 3V3 rails in Revision 3 to keep the voltage nice and clean.

image940×920 116 KB

SpiderLAN Revision 2 and Revision 3

Revision 4 was all about size, since this was about the time we started looking at getting these on robots. We took what we learnt from Revision 3 and tried to shove it into a much smaller package. We made our first adventure into double-sided assembly, allowing us to put the chunky STM32F7 MCU on the reverse side of the board. We also dropped a lot of the I/O – sacrificing an additional four digital I/O, some PWM, and RS485‡ connections in favour of a smaller size.

image733×652 60.8 KB

SpiderLAN Revision 4

We even got some nice enclosures 3D printed at an industrial fab, which produced some really clean results.

image788×553 26.3 KB

SpiderLAN Revision 4 in its black 3D printed enclosure.

Revision 5 is all about making the board more suitable for FRC. What’s a great way of reducing the total space taken up by your electronics? To mount them on top of each other! Here’s where we introduced the MXP connector, along with a slick white PCB. Previously removed I/O is now re-exposed as pin headers for future expansion, and all connectors changed to be vertical mount to reduce the horizontal sprawl of the board due to the sheer size of ethernet plugs and jackets (as well as to not obscure the RoboRIO’s I/O). We also gave the PCB a nice layer of conformal coating to keep it protected without the need for an external enclosure.

image828×809 80.3 KB

SpiderLAN Revision 5

And that brings us to the end. You’ll notice I haven’t touched on the software side of this “smart” switch, or why there’s a seemingly out-of-place CAN bus onboard, and the reason for that is simple – we’re going to integrate components of it into future products. Speaking of future products…

What’s next for Grapple?

Well, this isn’t the only thing we’ve been developing. There’s a few small devices I’m trying to get out by the end of this year (and I mean small literally – they’re the size of an Australian postage stamp). There’s also a big project that we’re working on. It’s ambitious, and way more complex than the SpiderLAN, but if we can make it work, it’ll have a big impact.

Developing for Education

There is another thing I wanted to touch on in this post, and that’s that we’re going to be operating a little differently at Grapple. I’ve always been a firm believer in open-source software and hardware, especially when you’re in the education market, which is why all production devices we make at Grapple are going to be 100% open-source – hardware and software. No opaque native libraries, no hidden specs, no paid subscriptions – every device that ends up in the hands of teams will be completely open (unless there’s a safety reason not to do so, or we’ve signed an NDA for whatever reason). We’re making products for a program that’s all about education and teaching the next generation, so I’m going to put my money where my mouth is and let you all come along for the ride.

There is, of course, a balancing act to this. To avoid the larger FRC vendors from taking our designs while they’re still in development, we’ll only be open sourcing once the devices are ready to be released into the market. Unfortunately, this includes the SpiderLAN since we will be using components of it in future products. However, if there’s enough interest and this product does make it to market, you have my word it will be 100% open on release day.

Footnotes
† The especially keen-eyed will notice that 6 is ‘G’ if you zero-index the alphabet

‡ Why RS485? Well, it’s the standard used for DMX – the protocol used in stage lighting. When these boards were originally scoped for use at WARP (our offseason), we wanted to be able to connect light bars to these boards to provide Ethernet-addressable alliance lighting. In the end, we didn’t get to do the lighting, but we have a separate board located at the scoring table which now handles DMX control for future events!

LaSalle","username":"robo5142","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/r/b2d939/{size}.png","created_at":"2023-11-11T15:28:16.708Z","cooked":"

This is a cool development program you have taken on and I certainly applaud your effort and entrepreneurial spirit. But with the Roborio being retired and an RFP out for a new controller, will this affect the continued need for this in FRC? NI will still sell the Rio to customers other than FRC so there is market there to explore as well.

Good observation, that’s another one of the reasons that I’ve decided to not carry through with this product, at least in the short term. That being said, you can run this completely off the RoboRIO on its own, so as an industrial Ethernet switch it still has some merit. Perhaps I will take the project further in the new year, but for now I’m going to set my sights on some other projects hopefully for distribution by EOY.

Jaci:

two of which provide 18V regulated passive PoE

I wouldn’t discount your product at all, in light of the fact that the new radio doesn’t regulate it’s passive PoE output at all, which I see as unacceptable. I’m glad to see that you regulate your PoE output. It would be great if they could learn from your example.

I will say since it appears that you don’t have dip switches or anything to turn off PoE, it might be nice to make those ports yellow.
